claim: Harvard research shows that people vaccinated against the Covid-19 are at greatest risk from the coronavirus Delta variant that causes the disease.
label: MISLEADING

claim: The false or unproven claims about COVID-19 vaccines in the letter addressed to the president of the Valencia College of Physicians
label: FALSE

claim: In the post we are reviewing, an object (spoon) glued to the shoulder of an allegedly vaccinated person is once again presented.
label: FALSE

claim: The presidents of Tanzania, Haiti, and Burundi were killed for opposing vaccines.
label: FALSE

claim: Those who are exposed to the delta variant of the virus that causes the COVID-19 are “twice as likely to require hospitalization if the person was vaccinated.”
label: FALSE

claim: If people can transmit Covid-19 even when vaccinated, there is no logic in vaccination.
label: Misleading

claim: In France, police applaud demonstrators which entered against «forced vaccination».
label: FALSE

claim: 62% of people vaccinated against the COVID-19 have irreversible heart damage.
label: FALSE

claim: Vaccines purportedly contain a cancer-causing substance called graphene oxide.
label: MISLEADING

claim: The vaccines that were supposed to be stored at -75 degrees Celsius are distributed in the middle of the village in a tractor-trailer at plus 40 degrees.
label: FALSE

claim: Another measure is remote immunization with the help of the military, police, and sniper services. That is, hunting unvaccinated and shooting them with vaccine ammunition. The shooting will be done with special harmless bullets on the top of which a vaccine ampoule is mounted, with an arrow that stabs the prey and injects its contents in contact. Desirable targets would be the neck, shoulders, thighs, etc. Stomach, back, and legs are also acceptable although not ideal. With this measure, in 3 days maximum, the immunization should be completed up to 100 percent.
label: FALSE

claim: President Joe Biden announces Americans not vaccinated before 2022 will be put in camps.
label: FALSE

claim: Photo shows protest against vaccination against the COVID-19 in France.
label: FALSE

claim: The vaccine is not effective against RNA viruses.
label: PARTLY FALSE
